details.purpose: The primary purpose is to support a typical face to face contact with a patient during which vital signs such as blood pressure, temperature, pulse rate etc are measured and recorded, including overall vital sign scores such as NEWS and Glasgow Coma Scale. The template can also be used for patient-reported vital signs and could be populated via external devices as well.

term_definitions.items: Additional composition metadata aligned with IHE-XDS which is not already available from the Reference Model COMPOSITION class.
The speciality of the author/composer of the document.
For example: Report, Summary, Images, Plan, Patient Preferences, Workflow. These codes are specific to an XDS Affinity Domain.
A high-level document class code, normally selected from a valueset provided by the IHE-XDS Affinity Domain.
for example: Pulmonary History and Physical, Discharge Summary, Ultrasound Report. These codes are specific to an XDS Affinity Domain.
The code specifying the precise type of document from the user perspective. Normally selected from a valueset provided by the local IHE-XDS Affinity Domain or national standard.
Coded text is preferred, normally specific to an XDS Affinity Domain.
A term specifying the level of confidentiality of the XDS Document.
Coded text is preferred. The codes are specific to an XDS Affinity Domain.
A term defining the healthcare facility type.
For example: Family Practice, Laboratory, Radiology. Coded text is preferred, normally specific to an XDS Affinity Domain.
The code specifying the clinical specialty where the act that resulted in the document was performed.
Additional metadata about the document itself, including size, url.
This list of codes represents the main clinical acts.
The observed characteristics of spontaneous breathing as would commonly be recorded as part of a 'vital signs' examination.
Respiratory pattern or single word, phrase or brief description which represents the clinical meaning and significance of the measurements.
Deep chest breathing with or without a visible gasp.
Periods of hyperventilation alternating with periods of apnoea.
Breathing of varying tidal volumes and rates.
Deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief, insufficient release of breath.
Clusters of irregular breaths that alternate with periods of apnoea. Also termed Biot's breathing.

Subject's level of exertion at or just prior to the observation being made. Intended only to record exertion only as it might effect respirations and where it would not normally be recorded as part of general clinical observation.
The respiratory expiratory phase is longer than normal/usual. Associated with obstructive airways disease such as asthma.
Details of the amount of oxygen being delivered to the subject at the time of observation. Assumed values of 21% oxygen concentration, Fi02 of 0.21 and oxygen flow rate of 0 l/min or 0 ml/min.
Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the respirations observation. For example, level of anxiety, pain, feeding in infants, tracheostomy.
e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with HL7 or CDISC equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.

An instrument, apparatus, implant, material or similar, used in the provision of healthcare. In this context, a medical device includes a broad range of devices which act through a variety of physical, mechanical, thermal or similar means but specifically excludes devices which act through medicinal means such as pharmacological, metabolic or immunological methods. The scope is inclusive of disposable devices as well as durable or persisting devices that require tracking, maintenance activities or regular calibration, recognising that each type of device has specific data recording requirements.

This data element will capture the term, phrase or category used in clinical practice. For example: <brand name><machine> (XYZ Audiometer); <size> <brand name> <intravenous catheter> (14G Jelco IV catheter); or <brand name/type> <implant>. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible, although this may be local and depending on local supplies available.
Identification of the medical device, preferably by a common name, a formal fully descriptive name or, if required, by class or category of device.
Narrative description of the medical device.

Not applicable if a category is already recorded in 'Device name'. Example: if the 'Device' is named as a 'urinary catheter'; the 'Type' may be recorded as 'indwelling' or 'condom'.Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible. This may include use of GTIN or EAN numbers.
The category or kind of device.
The number assigned by the manufacturer which identifies a group of items manufactured at the same time, usually found on the label or packaging material.
This date usually applies only to single use or disposable devices.
Date after which the device/product is no longer fit for use, usually found on the device itself or printed on the accompanying packaging.
Additional narrative about the device not captured in other fields.
Further details about specific properties about the medical device.
Additional structured informations about identified components of the device.
For example: Owner, Contact details, Location, Network address, Date due for replacement, Calibration details etc.
Further details about management and maintenance of the device.
Number assigned by the manufacturer which can be found on the device, and should be specific to each device., its label, or accompanying packaging.
Often fixed to the device as a barcode.
A numeric or alphanumeric string that is associated with this device within a given system.
The exact number assigned by the manufacturer, as it appears in the manufacturer's catalogue, device labeling, or accompanying packaging.
The exact model number assigned by the manufacturer and found on the device label or accompanying packaging.
Coding of the name of the identifier with a coding system is desirable, if available.
Unspecified identifier, which can be further specified in a template or at run time.

When the medical device is an actual software application, record the version of the software using this data element. When the medical device has multiple software applications embedded within it, record each software component in a separate CLUSTER archetype within the Components SLOT - either as a nested instance of another CLUSTER.device archetype or using a CLUSTER archetype designed specifically for recording software details (but not yet available at time of this archetype development).
Identification of the version of software being used in the medical device.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: a technical diagram of a device, or a digital image.
The amount of oxygen being delivered, or to be delivered, to the patient given as a fraction, percentage or indirectly as a flow rate.
Oxygen flow rate given to an individual.
Fraction of oxygen in inspired air.
Percentage of oxygen in inspired air.
Intended to capture only simple description / terms, for example: 'nasal prongs'. The 'Oxygen delivery detail' slot may be used for more detailed or complex recording.
The method used to deliver the oxygen.
Where 'On air' is set to true, Flow rate, FiO and Percent O should not be recorded. Conversely 'On air' should be omitted if Flow rate, FiO or Percent O are recorded.
The patient is receiving air, equivalent to 21% O or 0.21 FiO and an oxygen flow rate of 0 litres per minute.
For example details of humidification or assisted ventilation.
Further details of the method of oxygen delivery.
Blood oxygen and related measurements, measured by pulse oximetry or pulse CO-oximetry.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
SpO is defined as the percentage of oxyhaemoglobin (HbO) to the total concentration of haemoglobin (HbO + deoxyhaemoglobin) in peripheral blood.
The saturation of oxygen in the peripheral blood, measured via pulse oximetry.
For example: Right index finger, left earlobe. Coding with a terminology is preferred, if possible.
The site of the measurement sensor.
Assumed values of 21% oxygen concentration, Fi0 of 0.21 and oxygen flow rate of 0 l/min or 0 ml/min.
Details of the amount of oxygen available to the subject at the time of observation.
For example, motion, pain, poor perfusion, infant feeding, peripheral hypothermia, sedation.
Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be affect interpretation of the observation.
Details of the non-invasive oximetry device used.
Details about physical activity undertaken at the time of measurement.
A text comment about the pulse oximetry result.
The oxygen content of the peripheral blood, calculated based on pulse oximetry and pulse CO-oximetry.
The saturation of carboxyhaemoglobin in the peripheral blood, measured via pulse CO-oximetry.
The saturation of methaemoglobin in the peripheral blood, measured via pulse CO-oximetry.
A waveform reading associated with the oximetry measurement.
Coding with a terminology is preferred, if possible. For example, normal oxygen saturation or hypoxaemia.
Single word, phrase or brief description which represents the clinical meaning and significance of the measurements.
e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with HL7 or CDISC equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.

Details of a series of oximetry readings, other than waveforms, expressed as a multimedia image or series of images. Waveforms should be recorded using the Waveform slot and associated cluster archetype.
Sensor site relative to the ductus arteriosus in neonates, to determine whether the blood supply to limb of the sensor site is pre- or post-ductal in cases of patent ductus arteriosus.
Unable to assess whether the sensor site is pre- or post-ductal.
Record details about the rate and associated attributes for a pulse or heart beat.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Run-time name constraints have been specified, in order to simplify the renaming of this data element to Pulse Rate or Heart Rate, as required.
The rate, measured in beats per minute.
Is the pulse or heart beat regular?
The pattern is irregular in a regular pattern,. For example, a dropped beat once every 'n' beats.
The pattern is irregular in a chaotic and unpredictable manner. For example, atrial fibrillation.
The body position of the subject during the observation.
The subject was sitting (for example on bed or chair).
The subject was reclining at an approximate angle of 45 degrees, with the legs elevated to the level of the pelvis.
The subject was standing, walking or running.
It can be implied that the pulse is present if Rate >0 beats/min.
Presence of a pulse or heart beat.
Details about the device used to measure the pulse rate or heart rate.
Details about physical exertion being undertaken during the examination.
For example, presence of a pacemaker, level of anxiety; pain or fever etc.
Narrative description about any incidental factors that may affect interpretation of the physical findings.
For example, auscultation or electronic monitoring.
Method used to observe the pulse or heart beat.
Narrative description about the pulse or heart beat.
Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: Bradycardia, Extrasystoles or Sinus rhythm. Multiple statements are allowed.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the pulse or heart beat findings, including the rhythm.
A pulse or heart beat can be detected.
A pulse or heart beat cannot be detected.
The pulse rate, measured in beats per minute.
The heart rate, measured in beats per minute.
Coding with a terminology is desired, where possible. For example: full, thready, bounding, slow rising, or collapsing. Multiple terms may be recorded.
Description of the character of the pulse or heart beat.
The findings are observed by physical touch of the observer on the subject.
The findings are observed with the assistance of a device, such as a stethoscope.
The findings are observed non-invasively using a device such as a pulse oximeter or a stethoscope.
Maximum pulse rate or heart rate observed during a period of exertion.
Body site where the pulse or heart beat were observed.
The findings are observed invasively using a device such as an arterial catheter.
The lobe of an unspecified ear.
Selection of a value from this value set is only valid if 'Irregular' is selected from the 'Regularity' data element.
More specific pattern of an irregular pulse or heart beat.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
Generic label to allow for any or all statements about the pulse or heart beat.
Specific conclusion about the rhythm of the pulse or heartbeat, drawn from a combination of the heart rate, pattern and other characteristics observed on examination.
Additional narrative about the pulse or heart beat findings not captured in other fields.
A measurement of the body temperature, which is a surrogate for the core body temperature of the individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The measured body temperature (as a surrogate for the core of the body).
The anatomical site of measurement of the temperature.
Temperature is measured within the mouth.
Temperature is measured from within the external auditory canal.
Temperature is measured from the skin of the axilla with the arm positioned down by the side.
Temperature is measured within the nasopharynx.
Temperature is measured in the urinary bladder.
Temperature is measured within the vascular system.
The degree of exposure of the individual at the time of measurement.
The person is covered by a lesser amount of clothing or bedding than deemed appropriate for the environmental circumstances.
The person is covered by an amount of clothing or bedding deemed appropriate for the environmental circumstances.
The person is covered by an increased amount of clothing or bedding than deemed appropriate for the environmental circumstances.
Description of the conditions applied to the subject that might influence their measured body temperature.
Temperature is measured from exposed skin.
Temperature is measured within the vagina.
Temperatue is measured within the oesophagus.
Temperature is measured in the inguinal skin crease between the leg and abdominal wall.
Details about the environmental conditions at the time of temperature measurement.
Details about the exertion of the person at the time of temperature measurement.
Details about the device use to measure body temperature.
Temperature is measured at the temple, over the superficial temporal artery.
Temperature is measured on the forehead.
e.g. Local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
Additional comment about the body temperature measurement not captured in other fields.
Structured anatomical location of where the measurement was taken.
Number of days since onset of last normal menstrual period.

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial pressure in the systemic circulation. Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The position of the subject at the time of measurement.
Perloff D, Grim C, Flack J, Frohlich ED, Hill M, McDonald M, Morgenstern BZ. Human blood pressure determination by sphygmomanometry. Circulation 1993;88;2460-2470.
The size of the cuff used for blood pressure measurement.
Simple body site where blood pressure was measured.
A cuff used for an adult thigh.
A cuff for adults with larger arms.
A cuff that is standard for an adult.
The right arm of the person.
The left arm of the person.
The right thigh of the person.
The left thigh of the person.
Additional narrative about the measurement, not captured in other fields.
Standing at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Reclining at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Lying flat at the time of blood pressure measurement.
PLEASE NOTE: '' is a valid UCUM unit. Please use 'deg' as the correct unit.
The craniocaudal tilt of the surface on which the person is lying at the time of measurement.
The average arterial pressure that occurs over the entire course of the heart contraction and relaxation cycle.
The difference between the systolic and diastolic pressure.
A cuff used for a small adult.
A cuff that is appropriate for a child or adult with a thin arm.
Record which Korotkoff sound is used for determining diastolic pressure using auscultative method.
The fourth Korotkoff sound is identified as an abrupt muffling of sounds.
The fifth Korotkoff sound is identified by absence of sounds as the cuff pressure drops below the diastolic blood pressure.
Lying flat with some lateral tilt, usually angled towards the left side. Commonly required in the last trimester of pregnancy to relieve aortocaval compression.
A cuff used for a neonate, assuming cuff is the appropriate size for maturity and birthweight of the neonate.
The right wrist of the subject.
The left wrist of the subject.
Details about sphygmomanometer or other device used to measure the blood pressure.
The right ankle of the subject.
Details about physical activity undertaken at the time of blood pressure measurement.
The left ankle of the subject.

Use 'Location of measurement' to select from a value set of common sites or free text choice. Use SLOT for 'Structured measurement location' to record unusual sites, such as intra-arterial catheter sites. 'Specific location' has been deprecated.
Body location where blood pressure is measured.
Data element deprecated, and replaced by free text component of 'Location of measurement' data type.
Method of measurement of blood pressure.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a stethoscope and Korotkoff sounds.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using palpation (usually of the brachial or radial arteries).
Formula used to calculate the Mean Arterial Pressure (if recorded in data).
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a blood pressure machine.
Method of measuring blood pressure internally ie involving penetration of the skin and measuring inside blood vessels.
Estimate of the average blood pressure over a 24 hour period.
Sleep status - supports interpretation of 24 hour ambulatory blood pressure records.
Subject is in the natural state of bodily rest.

Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the blood pressure measurement. For example, level of anxiety or 'white coat syndrome'; pain or fever; changes in atmospheric pressure etc.
Invasive measurement via transducer access line within an artery.
Formula used to calculate the systolic pressure from from mean arterial pressure (if recorded in data).
Formula used to calculate the diastolic pressure from mean arterial pressure (if recorded in data).
Structured anatomical location of where the measurement was taken.
For example: Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
Simple scale used as part of an assessment to measure and record an individual's level of consciousness. AVPU is an acronym for 'Alert', 'Voice', 'Pain', 'Unresponsive'.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The observation of the patient's level of consciousness.
Eyes open spontaneously, oriented speech, obeys commands.
Any verbal, motor or eye response to a voice stimulus.
Any verbal, motor or eye response to a pain stimulus, such as pressing the nail root, but not to voice stimulus.
No response to voice or pain stimuli.
This element should be coded with a terminology, where possible. For example: pressing the nail root or the sternum.
Description of the type of pain stimulus used to elicit the observation.
e.g. Local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
Additional narrative about the observation, not captured in other fields.
Narrative description of any issues or factors that may impact on the observation.
The patient has new-onset confusion, disorientation and/or agitation, where previously their mental state was normal.
Simple scale used as part of an assessment to measure and record an individual's level of consciousness. AVPU is an acronym for 'Alert', 'Voice', 'Pain', 'Unresponsive'.
Simple scale used as part of an assessment to measure and record an individual's level of consciousness. ACVPU is an acronym for 'Alert', 'Confusion', 'Voice', 'Pain', 'Unresponsive'.!
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The observation of the patient's level of consciousness.
The observation of the patient's level of consciousness.
Eyes open spontaneously, oriented speech, obeys commands.
Any verbal, motor or eye response to a voice stimulus.
Any verbal, motor or eye response to a pain stimulus, such as pressing the nail root, but not to voice stimulus.
No response to voice or pain stimuli.
This element should be coded with a terminology, where possible. For example: pressing the nail root or the sternum.
Description of the type of pain stimulus used to elicit the observation.
e.g. Local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
Additional narrative about the observation, not captured in other fields.
Narrative description of any issues or factors that may impact on the observation.

NEWS (National Early Warning Score) is a simple score used to provide an objective indication of a patient's degree of clinical deterioration. This version follows guidance issued by the UK Royal College of Physicians.
A specific date and/or time which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Range category for the systolic blood pressure (SBP) measurement of a patient.
Range category for the heart rate (HR) measurement of a patient.
Range category for the respiratory rate (RR) measurement of a patient.
Range category for the body temperature (Temp) measurement of a patient.
Observed category for the AVPU scale rating of a patient's conscious state.
The heart rate measurement is less than/equal to 40 beats/min or greater than/equal to 131 beats/min; scored as 3 points.
The heart rate measurement is between 111 and 130 beats/min; scored as 2 points.
The heart rate measurement is between 41 and 50 beats/min or between 91 and 110 beats/min; scored as 1 point.
The heart rate measurement is between 51 and 90 beats/min; scored as 0 points.
The systolic blood pressure measurement is between 111 and 219 mmHg; scored as 0 points.
The systolic blood pressure measurement is between 101 and 110 mmHg; scored as 1 point.
The systolic blood pressure measurement is between 91 and 100 mmHg; scored as 2 points.
The systolic blood pressure measurement is less than/equal to 90 mmHg or greater than/equal to 220 mmHg; scored as 3 points.
The respiratory rate measurement is between 12 and 20 breaths/min; scored as 0 points.
The respiratory rate measurement is between 9 and 11 breaths/min; scored as 1 point.
The respiratory rate measurement is between 21 and 24 breaths/min; scored as 2 points.
The respiratory rate measurement is less than/equal to 8 breaths/min or greater than/equal to 25 breaths/min; scored as 3 points.
The body temperature measurement is between 36.1 and 38.0 degrees Celsius; scored as 0 points.
The body temperature measurement is between 35.1 and 36.0 degrees Celsius or between 38.1 and 39.0 degrees Celsius; scored as 1 point.
The patient is alert or awake; scored as 0 points.
The patient responds only to verbal, pain or stimulus; scored as 3 points.
Total score may be generated at run-time.
The total sum of all the NEWS parameter ordinals.
Range category for the oxygen saturation measurement of a patient.
The oxygen saturation level is greater than/equal to 96%;scored as 0 points.
The oxygen saturation level is between 94% and 95%; scored as 1 point.
The oxygen saturation level is between 92% and 93%; scored as 2 points.
The oxygen saturation level is less than/equal to 91%; scored as 3 points.
Range category depending on whether the patient is receiving supplemental oxygen.
The patient is not receiving supplemental oxygen; scored as 0 points.
The patient is receiving supplemental oxygen; scored as 2 points.
The body temperature is greater than/equal to 39.1 degrees Celcius; scored as 2 points.
The body temperature is less than/equal to 35 degrees Celcius ; scored as 3 points.
For example: If the patient has COPD.
Description of any incidental factors that may have contributed to the score.
Additional narrative about the overall NEWS score not captured in other fields.
e.g. Local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.

An instrument, apparatus, implant, material or similar, used in the provision of healthcare. In this context, a medical device includes a broad range of devices which act through a variety of physical, mechanical, thermal or similar means but specifically excludes devices which act through medicinal means such as pharmacological, metabolic or immunological methods. The scope is inclusive of disposable devices as well as durable or persisting devices that require tracking, maintenance activities or regular calibration, recognising that each type of device has specific data recording requirements.

This data element will capture the term, phrase or category used in clinical practice. For example: <brand name><machine> (XYZ Audiometer); <size> <brand name> <intravenous catheter> (14G Jelco IV catheter); or <brand name/type> <implant>. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible, although this may be local and depending on local supplies available.
Identification of the medical device, preferably by a common name, a formal fully descriptive name or, if required, by class or category of device.
Narrative description of the medical device.

Not applicable if a category is already recorded in 'Device name'. Example: if the 'Device' is named as a 'urinary catheter'; the 'Type' may be recorded as 'indwelling' or 'condom'.Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible. This may include use of GTIN or EAN numbers.
The category or kind of device.
The number assigned by the manufacturer which identifies a group of items manufactured at the same time, usually found on the label or packaging material.
This date usually applies only to single use or disposable devices.
Date after which the device/product is no longer fit for use, usually found on the device itself or printed on the accompanying packaging.
Additional narrative about the device not captured in other fields.
Further details about specific properties about the medical device.
Additional structured informations about identified components of the device.
For example: Owner, Contact details, Location, Network address, Date due for replacement, Calibration details etc.
Further details about management and maintenance of the device.
Number assigned by the manufacturer which can be found on the device, and should be specific to each device., its label, or accompanying packaging.
Often fixed to the device as a barcode.
A numeric or alphanumeric string that is associated with this device within a given system.
The exact number assigned by the manufacturer, as it appears in the manufacturer's catalogue, device labeling, or accompanying packaging.
The exact model number assigned by the manufacturer and found on the device label or accompanying packaging.
Coding of the name of the identifier with a coding system is desirable, if available.
Unspecified identifier, which can be further specified in a template or at run time.

When the medical device is an actual software application, record the version of the software using this data element. When the medical device has multiple software applications embedded within it, record each software component in a separate CLUSTER archetype within the Components SLOT - either as a nested instance of another CLUSTER.device archetype or using a CLUSTER archetype designed specifically for recording software details (but not yet available at time of this archetype development).
Identification of the version of software being used in the medical device.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: a technical diagram of a device, or a digital image.
The amount of oxygen being delivered, or to be delivered, to the patient given as a fraction, percentage or indirectly as a flow rate.
Oxygen flow rate given to an individual.
Fraction of oxygen in inspired air.
Percentage of oxygen in inspired air.
Intended to capture only simple description / terms, for example: 'nasal prongs'. The 'Oxygen delivery detail' slot may be used for more detailed or complex recording.
The method used to deliver the oxygen.
Where 'On air' is set to true, Flow rate, FiO and Percent O should not be recorded. Conversely 'On air' should be omitted if Flow rate, FiO or Percent O are recorded.
The patient is receiving air, equivalent to 21% O or 0.21 FiO and an oxygen flow rate of 0 litres per minute.
For example details of humidification or assisted ventilation.
Further details of the method of oxygen delivery.

NEWS2 (National Early Warning Score) is a simple score used to provide an objective indication of a patient's degree of clinical deterioration. This version follows updated guidance issued by the UK Royal College of Physicians.
A specific date and/or time which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Range category for the systolic blood pressure (SBP) measurement of a patient.
Range category for the pulse measurement of a patient.
Range category for the respiratory rate (RR) measurement of a patient.
Range category for the body temperature (Temp) measurement of a patient.
Observed category for the AVPU scale rating of a patient's conscious state.
The pulse measurement is less than/equal to 40 beats/min or greater than/equal to 131 beats/min; scored as 3 points.
The pulse measurement is between 111 and 130 beats/min; scored as 2 points.
The pulse measurement is between 41 and 50 beats/min or between 91 and 110 beats/min; scored as 1 point.
The pulse measurement is between 51 and 90 beats/min; scored as 0 points.
The systolic blood pressure measurement is between 111 and 219 mmHg; scored as 0 points.
The systolic blood pressure measurement is between 101 and 110 mmHg; scored as 1 point.
The systolic blood pressure measurement is between 91 and 100 mmHg; scored as 2 points.
The systolic blood pressure measurement is less than/equal to 90 mmHg or greater than/equal to 220 mmHg; scored as 3 points.
The respiratory rate measurement is between 12 and 20 breaths/min; scored as 0 points.
The respiratory rate measurement is between 9 and 11 breaths/min; scored as 1 point.
The respiratory rate measurement is between 21 and 24 breaths/min; scored as 2 points.
The respiratory rate measurement is less than/equal to 8 breaths/min or greater than/equal to 25 breaths/min; scored as 3 points.
The body temperature measurement is between 36.1 and 38.0 degrees Celsius; scored as 0 points.
The body temperature measurement is between 35.1 and 36.0 degrees Celsius or between 38.1 and 39.0 degrees Celsius; scored as 1 point.
The patient is alert or awake; scored as 0 points.
The patient is confused or responds only to verbal, pain or stimulus; scored as 3 points.
Total score may be generated at run-time.
The total sum of all the NEWS parameter ordinals.
Range category for the oxygen saturation measurement of a patient.
The oxygen saturation level is greater than/equal to 96%;scored as 0 points.
The oxygen saturation level is between 94% and 95%; scored as 1 point.
The oxygen saturation level is between 92% and 93%; scored as 2 points.
The oxygen saturation level is less than/equal to 91%; scored as 3 points.
Range category depending on whether the patient is receiving supplemental oxygen.
The patient is not receiving supplemental oxygen; scored as 0 points.
The patient is receiving supplemental oxygen; scored as 2 points.
The body temperature is greater than/equal to 39.1 degrees Celcius; scored as 2 points.
The body temperature is less than/equal to 35 degrees Celcius ; scored as 3 points.
For example: If the patient has COPD.
Description of any incidental factors that may have contributed to the score.
Additional narrative about the overall NEWS score not captured in other fields.
e.g. Local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
Range category for the oxygen saturation measurement of a patient where the target range is 88-92%, e.g. in hypercapnic respiratory failure.
The oxygen saturation level is between 88% and 92% or greater than/equal to 93% on air; scored as 0 points.
The oxygen saturation level is between 86% and 87% or between 93% and 94% on oxygen; scored as 1 point.
The oxygen saturation level is between 84% and 85% or between 95% and 96% on oxygen; scored as 2 points.
The oxygen saturation level is less or equal 83% or between >=97% on oxygen; scored as 3 points.
Details of oxygen delivery or device.
Fifteen point scale used to assess impairment of consciousness in response to defined stimuli. More correctly known as the Modified Glasgow coma scale.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.

Most commonly, the score for verbal response will be selected from one of the ordinal values, however if a response cannot be tested, for example if the subject of care is intubated, then the "Not Applicable" null flavour should be recorded.
Best verbal response to test stimulus.

Most commonly, the score for motor response will be selected from one of the ordinal values, however if a response cannot be tested, for example if the subject of care cannot move their limbs due to injury or paralysis, then the "Not Applicable" null flavour should be recorded.
Best motor response to test stimulus.

Most commonly, the score for eye response will be selected from one of the ordinal values, however if a response cannot be tested, for example if the subject of care cannot physically open their eyes due to other injuries, then the "Not Applicable" null flavour should be recorded.
Best response of eyes to test stimulus.
No eye opening at any time, no interfering factor. For example: eyes closed by local swelling.
Eyes opening after finger tip stimulus.
Eyes opening after spoken or shouted request. Not to be confused with wakening of a sleeping person.
No audible response, no interfering factor. For example: intubation; profound deafness.
Correctly gives name, place and date.
No movement in arms/legs, no interfering factor. For example: paralysed.
Decerebrate extension of arms and/or legs in response to stimuli. For example: extends arm at elbow.
Slow, decorticate flexion of arms and/or legs. For example: bends arm at elbow, but features predominantly abnormal.
Rapid flexion in response to stimuli but features predominantly normal. For example: flexion of wrist when supra-orbital pressure applied; pulls part of body away when nailbed pinched.
Purposeful flexion towards painful stimuli. For example: brings hand above the clavicle when supra-orbital pressure is applied.

The Total Score may be derived as the sum of the three response data elements and, if so, should be validated by the clinical information system against the individual scores entered by the clinician to ensure there is no conflict or inconsistency. Do not report a total score when one or more components are not testable because the score will be artificially low - in this situation record the EVM profile.
The sum of the ordinal scores recorded for each of the three component responses.

The EMV Score may be automatically derived as a concatenation of the three response data elements and, if so, should be validated by the clinical information system against the individual scores entered by the clinician to ensure there is no conflict or inconsistency. The 'Not applicable' null flavour value should be recorded as 'NT', for 'not tested' as per http://www.glasgowcomascale.org/.
Alternative assessment to 'Total Score' where the Eye Verbal Motor profile is expressed as three discrete components.
Record the reasons for inability to test in the 'Confounding factors' data element.
Additional narrative about the measurement of the scale not captured in other fields.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.

For example: deafness; aphasia; language issues; use of sedatives; hypothermia; or paralysis, severe facial/eye swelling or tracheal intubation as reasons for inability to record any one of the ordinal E, V or M assessments.
Narrative record of factors that may have contributed to the GCS scores.
Narrative summary or overview about a patient, specifically from the perspective of a healthcare provider, and with or without associated interpretations.
The summary, assessment, conclusions or evaluation of the clinical findings.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
A group of observations that are recorded at the same time and record the blood pressure, pulse, temperature and other readings.
Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s).
e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
